content: MIL-101­(Cr) was synthesized hydrothermally based on the recipe from the literature. First, 800 mg of Cr­(NO3)3·9H2O and 332 mg of H2BDC (terephthalic acid) were blended in 10 mL of deionized (DI) water for 1 h. To the mixture were also added 1.5 mL of 36% acetic acid and about 5 mg of MIL-101­(Cr) crystals as a modulator and a seed, respectively, for the synthesis. The solution was then placed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and kept in an oven at 200 °C for 12 h, followed by slow cooling with a rate of 1 °C/min to room temperature. After the synthesis, the MOF solids were separated using a centrifuge and washed repeatedly with MeOH, DMF, and MeOH two times each. The resulting MOF powders were dried under a high vacuum (about 10 mTorr) at 150 °C overnight for further analysis and amine impregnation.
clean_text:
Material Synthesis

MIL-101(Cr) was synthesized hydrothermally based on the recipe from the literature. First, 800 mg of Cr(NO3)3⋅9H2O and 332 mg of H2BDC (terephthalic acid) were blended in 10 mL of deionized (DI) water for 1 h. To the mixture were also added 1.5 mL of 36% acetic acid and about 5 mg of MIL-101(Cr) crystals as a modulator and a seed, respectively, for the synthesis. The solution was then placed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and kept in an oven at 200 °C for 12 h, followed by slow cooling with a rate of 1 °C/min to room temperature. After the synthesis, the MOF solids were separated using a centrifuge and washed repeatedly with MeOH, DMF, and MeOH two times each. The resulting MOF powders were dried under a high vacuum (about 10 mTorr) at 150 °C overnight for further analysis and amine impregnation.
